text: This TED Talk features author Bruce Renevossen, recorded live at TED NYC 2017.
label: Neutral

text: We want to tell you about a podcast we think you'll love.
label: Positive

text: 99% Invisible from PRX's Radio Topia.
label: Neutral

text: Ever wonder how inflatable men came to be regular fixtures at used car lots?
label: Neutral

text: Want to know why women's clothes typically don't have pockets?
label: Positive

text: 99% Invisible is all about the thought that goes into the things we don't think about.
label: Neutral

text: The unnoticed architecture and design that shape our world.
label: Neutral

text: You can listen and subscribe to 99% Invisible, hosted by Roman Mars, at 99%Invisible.org,
label: Neutral

text: or wherever you get your podcasts.

label: Neutral

label: Neutral

label: Neutral

label: Neutral

text: More at T-MobileForBusiness.com
label: Neutral

text: So what is capitalism?
label: Neutral

text: Capitalism fundamentally is a series of marketplaces.
label: Neutral

text: You could have a marketplace for lemonade, a marketplace for lemons, a marketplace for trucks
label: Neutral

text: that transport lemons, a marketplace that fuels those trucks, marketplaces that sell wood to build lemonade stands.
label: Neutral

text: However, capitalism, of course, as we know, is this either celebrated term or condemned term.
label: Positive

text: It's either revered or it's reviled.
label: Positive

text: And I'm here to argue that this is because capitalism in the modern iteration is largely misunderstood.
label: Negative

text: In my view, capitalism should not be thought of as an ideology, but instead should be thought of as an operating system.
label: Neutral

text: Think of your iPhone.
label: Neutral

text: Your iPhone merges hardware with software, apps and hardware.
label: Neutral

text: Now think about all the hardware as the physical reality all around you, and think of the apps as entrepreneurial activity, creative energy.
label: Positive

text: And in between, you have an operating system.
label: Neutral

text: As you have advances in hardware, you have advances in software.
label: Neutral

text: And the operating system needs to keep up.
label: Neutral

text: It needs to be patched. It needs to be updated.
label: Neutral

text: New releases have to happen.
label: Neutral

text: And all of these things have to happen symbiotically.
label: Neutral

text: The operating system needs to keep getting more and more advanced to keep up with innovation.
label: Positive

text: And this is why fundamentally, when you think about it as an operating system,
label: Neutral

text: it devolves the language of ideology away from what traditional defenders of capitalism think.
label: Positive

text: But even if you go to the Constitution, you'll notice, before the founders even got to the First Amendment with free speech, free religion, free press, they thought about patents and copyright.
label: Positive

text: They talked about the government's role in promoting arts and sciences.
label: Positive

text: It's the reason why I could not start a search engine tomorrow called Goggle.
label: Neutral

text: Goggle doesn't own G's, but I couldn't do it because there could be some confusion.
label: Negative

text: So even property rights have ambiguity built into that.
label: Neutral

text: And on and on.
label: Neutral

text: And by 1900, you have other types of property that come into being.
label: Neutral

text: For instance, imagine that in 1900, you owned 100 acres of land, some place in the Midwest.
label: Neutral

text: It's very easy to see where your fence ends, your neighbor's property begins.
label: Positive

text: Now let me ask you, where in the sky does your property end?
label: Neutral

text: Does it end at 1000 feet, 5000 feet, 10,000 feet?
label: Neutral

text: It makes no difference because other than the novelty of a few hot air balloons, man couldn't fly.
label: Negative

text: But within three years, he could.
label: Neutral

text: Now, all of a sudden, it was very much relevant whether your land ends at 1000 feet in the sky, 5000 feet, 10,000 feet, and you have to have someone arbitrate that.
label: Neutral

text: And indeed, that's exactly what happened in five or 10 years from now when Amazon wants to deliver a package over your house to your neighbor from that UPS truck, we're going to have to decide does your property end at five feet, 10 feet, 50 feet, 100 feet, where does it end?
label: Positive

text: And there is no ideology that'll tell you where your property ends.
label: Negative

text: It's an operating system.
label: Neutral

text: And similarly, we're going to see this with automobiles.
label: Neutral

text: A few years after the Wright Brothers figured out flight, human beings started using more and more cars.
label: Neutral

text: And all of a sudden, the regulatory system, the operating system had to be patched to all of a sudden address the safety of consumers.
label: Positive

text: That the consumers of vehicles were presenting danger to horses, other pedestrians, trolleys, what have you.
label: Negative

text: And all of a sudden, the driver of these automobiles had to have driver's licenses.
label: Neutral

text: Iexams registered motor vehicles, speed limits, rules of the road so that horses, pedestrians could coexist with cars.
label: Neutral

text: It had to be backwards compatible.
label: Neutral

text: So a new invention had to basically fit advances from the past.
label: Positive

text: Similarly, five or 10 years from now, we're going to see the same thing with self-driving cars, coexisting with human-driven cars.
label: Neutral

text: The reason why this is important is in 10 years, another thing is going to happen beyond drones in self-driving cars.
label: Positive

text: But you're going to see the most valuable economy in the world, the largest economy in the world, is going to be a country run by communists.
label: Positive

text: The Chinese seem to be very good at capitalism.
label: Positive

text: And this is going to have fundamental problems and present an identity crisis for the United States.
label: Negative

text: Because for a long time, free markets coincided with liberties such as free speech, free press, free religion, and all of a sudden this equation is going to be decoupled.
label: Positive

text: And when it gets decoupled, we might find the democracy, the multitude of voices actually impedes capitalism because a state that does not have any pretense of limited government can very quickly mandate a regulatory framework for drones, for electric cars.
label: Negative

text: For self-driving cars, for any new innovation where they feel that they can leapfrog Western societies.
label: Positive

text: And this is a very unique thing in the American experience.
label: Neutral

text: And this is why it's very important to think of American capitalism as an operating system and not as an ideology.
label: Positive

text: Because when you think about it as an ideology, you can have good politics make for very, very bad policy.
label: Negative

text: That market outcomes and democratic voices and battles for votes can end up stifling progress.
label: Positive

text: So over the next few years, as this political cycle plays out, you're going to see American democracy rise to meet the challenges that capitalism poses and modernity poses.
label: Positive

text: And I ask policy makers to think about decoupling ideology from economics and think about how good policy can ultimately become good politics. Thank you.
label: Positive

text: For more TED Talks, go to TED.com
label: Neutral
